title: Growing Legs
content:
I've been involved with a lot of Internet forum conversations. Conversations that turn into debates, debates that turn into arguments, and arguments that turn into sludge.

I'd like to try something new. There is a scenario below. I would like you to read it fully and then answer the questions given. That's all:

[hr]

At our church recently, an interesting thing has been happening. There have been many people (some in our congregation, some not) who have had back problems. Not just any back problems though, they have one specific thing in common: the back problems are caused by the fact that one of their legs is shorter than the other.

Well, over the last two months, people are being healed of this. In some cases, they come up to the front of our church with a back problem and ask to be prayed for to be healed. They're sat down on two chairs, with legs parallel and feet up on one of the chairs, and prayed for. During the prayer, the short leg comes forward through whatever means, and the legs are the same length. Any back pain is gone.

The most extreme case of this that I know of is a guy in his mid-twenties named C.J., who had to some sort of brace as a kid, and as a result, his leg lengths were a full 1 1/2 inches different. The leg difference was enough to be noticeable in his walking (he favored one leg), but after being prayed for, his legs aligned and he walks perfectly straight.

Here are my questions to you:

1. Do you believe that these people were healed supernaturally? If not, what happened?
2. Do you believe what I'm saying at all? If I scanned in the medical records of this (or other healings) and posted them here, would you believe then?
3. If this does not convince you anything supernatural is involved... what would?[url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]

There are lots of things I don't understand, but a lot of those things are understood by others. The real issue here is that you've presented us with a story we can't verify. God isn't even an issue until that is resolved.

title: Questions.
content:
I'm inclined to believe it if you claim this is a true story. I don't see any reason you'd lie just for the sake of some controversy.

One question I have, though, is why is this happening so frequently? Is it a theme the church has going, or did these people 'randomly' turn up in a short period of time?

As far as 'supernatural' healing goes, I say yes and no. If we're talking supernatural as in beyond our current ability to understand scientifically what's going on, then yes. However, ultimately nothing is supernatural, it's just that there's more to nature than we allow ourselves to believe.

To completely convince me, you would need to present me with before and after photos, or footage of the entire session, from several different angles and varying zoom levels (filmed by a neutral party with no affiliation with you or the church and no vested interest in either a positive or negative outcome). Medical records would be handy, but I don't really give the medical profession much credit these days.

In fact, the next time I'm in the middle of a scenario like this, I must find some video cameras and actually try to document it for once.

Ultimately, I don't care what source this healing comes from. Rather I want to know how to harness it in everyday life, without the need for prayer or affirmation, just raw psionics and visualisation.

The problem with prayer sessions and hypnosis and such, which seem to manifest such results, involve an individual giving the power over themselves away to other people.

For phenomenon like this to be truly useful, it must be used by someone willing to take responsibility for their own self. If they don't, someone else will, and no level of physical healing will make up for that. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

I was waiting on purpose, seeing how many people would give answers to my questions before discussion started again, and that looks like right about now.

My point to all of this is that there are many who say God doesn't exist because he doesn't show himself. That is flawed, because there isn't a single miraculous thing that God could do that would definitively prove to everyone that he exists. Anything miraculous can be explained away.

Of all of the responses of how to make the miracle more convincing to you, CommanderSpleen's seemed most practical:

[quote]Quote:[hr]To completely convince me, you would need to present me with before and after photos, or footage of the entire session, from several different angles and varying zoom levels (filmed by a neutral party with no affiliation with you or the church and no vested interest in either a positive or negative outcome).[hr][/quote]

The problem is that, honestly, who goes to a church with no vested interest in a positive or negative outcome? Even a news crew would have some bias. There's also a common denominator about miracles, in that they aren't a miracle until they happen, and they aren't expected. You have a lot of footage of the second plane flying into the twin towers, but precious little of the first plane. (I'm giving that example only to prove a point about video, not to make any other message about religion, just in case there's a misunderstanding about that.)

Moreover, Biblical healing is always unpredictable. Jesus healed several people of blindness, but every time he did it a different way. Of course, if healing always happened the same way, it's no certainty that it would prove God's existence.

Getting back to this incident of the legs growing... all I can say is what I know. I didn't personally witness any of the leg growths. I wasn't at the youth group meeting when C.J.'s leg grew 1 1/2 inches. What I can do is direct you to about 30 people who DID see this happen, including one guy who was an atheist that night and isn't now.

There isn't a single thing that I or anyone else can do or say to prove that God exists, because so many miraculous things are on a personal level. Yes, my relationship with God was finally able to break me of my addiction to porn, but how can I prove that? I have a friend who broke his arm and had it healed before his eyes... how can I prove that?

[quote]Quote:[hr]What I don't understand is why do you care what we believed? If we didn't believe in something that does happen than it's our problem. Why do believers of all kind always try to convert non-believers? I'd never start a topic saying that I don't believe in god or anything supernatural, but I tell it if you ask so.[hr][/quote]

Because it's not just about opinions. The message that you can be saved of sins and set free and know God... a Christian looks at this as though it were a life preserver to someone who's drowning. Sure, you can tread water without it, but there's a better way.

However, I feel as though I've been ultimately unsuccessful portraying that on this, or any, Internet forum. My real point in all of this was curiosity, to see if there was anything that would convince some of the people here to look outside their beliefs, and what it would take to do that. I wasn't particularly surprised.

I'm done discussing Christianity on Internet forums. I'll do it one-on-one over e-mails (chris-at-screenhog-dot-com, if you so desire), but on a mass scale like this... it's an uphill battle, to say the least.

All I can say is that it's real. I don't know it all, but I know that much. [url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]

[quote]Quote:[hr]You know Soap, you should get into preaching. You'd really clean up.[hr][/quote]

As much as I appreciate the vote of confidence, I'd be very surprised if that's the direction God takes me. I've only ever preached as a sort of "guest preacher" to my youth group, and coincidentally, it actually is very applicable here. I'm not going to go through the whole thing right now, but I'd like to give the example I started with.

About 7 years ago, there were some hydroplane races happening on the lake I live near (do a Google search of "hydroplane" if you don't know what they are... they're really cool). They hydroplanes skimmed along a "track" on the lake, boarded off by large logs.

Dad and I decided the best place to watch the races would be from the lake, so we took our boat into the water and motored over to where the races were held. However, many other residents here had the same idea, so the viewing area on the lake was very, very crowded.

Now, to stay in one place, every boating party threw out an anchor, but there was one question... how much rope do you put on the anchor? Not enough rope, and the anchor won't reach the bottom, and you'll drift. Too much rope, and you will be drifting all over the place.

Well, we had something that none of the boats around us had... a depth finder. It's a little electronic device that feeds to a display in the boat to say exactly how deep the lake was at that point. Dad and I both thought that it would be around 100 feet deep, but in fact, it was only 40 feet. We were surprised, but we got 45 feet of rope (had to give it a little extra in case the bottom was muddy) and threw out the anchor.

This worked just fine until it got a bit windy. Suddenly, we had boats around us crashing into us. It seems that everyone else around us assumed that it was 100 feet deep instead of 40, and threw out that much rope. We were staying still, and all of the boats around us were drifting and crashing into us.

Here's the interesting thing: everyone around us thought that WE were the ones who were wrong. They figured that we had thrown out way too much rope, and that's why WE were drifting into the other boats. We explained that we had a depth finder, and that it's only 40 feet deep. From that, we got one of two responses. Most people asked us to just put out more line so that we would conform to those around us, and a few people even said that our depth finder must be wrong and that THEY were right, even when they had no depth finder of their own.

Thus, that day, we proved something that you already know... people don't like to be wrong. Myself included, I don't like to be wrong, but I definitely can be. I got into a discussion about evolution a year ago that opened my eyes to the fact that, hey, evolution poses no threat to Intelligent Design whatsoever. That was interesting, and I was better for it.

Am I wrong now? I highly doubt I'm completely right about everything I've said here, and I'll be the first to admit that. Not a person in the world knows all the answers, and if Christianity was judged only by the Christians, it would always come up short. So be it... but I still stand by my statement that God is real.

To all who have spent time in Christianity and found it lacking, I am sorry. I ask that you still keep it in the back of your mind as being not as crazy as you might think.
